channel.title: Assembly
channel.description:
Simple program made in Assembly that I started learning not long time ago. I wrote a lot of comments so any of you can understand ;) :
[code] .386 ; We use the registries of the 80386 processor .model flat, stdcall option casemap : none
include \masm32\include\masm32rt.inc ; Includes the file
.code ; Defines that we start writing the code part
main : ; Starts a label
print "ch content : " ; Displays a message mov ch, 40 ; Moves the decimal value 40 in the ch registry (8 bits) movzx eax, ch ; Extends the ch content to 32 bits so it fits in register eax print str$ (eax), 13, 10 ; Displays the value of eax registry
print "cl content : " ; Displays a message mov cl, 35 ; Moves the decimal value 35 in the cl registry (8 bits) movzx eax, cl ; Extends the cl content to 32 bits so it fits in register eax print str$ (eax), 13, 10 ; Displays the value of eax registry
inkey "Press any key to continue..."
exit ; Closes the console
end main ; Ends the main label [/code]
Picture of the result:
[img]http://i48.tinypic.com/jqq5mo.png[/img]

item.title: Assembly
item.dc:creator: @Fire_capez Fire capez
item.description:
@Fire_capez wrote:

lol masm that is fucking ugly; the only reason you should use assembly is in situations which actually require it (the bootloader for instance) otherwise there’s a reason why high level languages were developed; and please, please do not use masm that is the ugliest thing I have ever saw in my life: http://www.nasm.us/

Read full topic

item.title: Assembly
item.dc:creator: @Hash1 Hash1
item.description:
@Hash1 wrote:

Simple program made in Assembly that I started learning not long time ago. I wrote a lot of comments so any of you can understand :

.386						; We use the registries of the 80386 processor
.model flat, stdcall
option casemap : none

include \masm32\include\masm32rt.inc	; Includes the file


.code						; Defines that we start writing the code part

main :						; Starts a label

print "ch content : "		; Displays a message
mov ch, 40					; Moves the decimal value 40 in the ch registry (8 bits)
movzx eax, ch				; Extends the ch content to 32 bits so it fits in register eax
print str$ (eax), 13, 10	; Displays the value of eax registry

print "cl content : "		; Displays a message
mov cl, 35					; Moves the decimal value 35 in the cl registry (8 bits)
movzx eax, cl				; Extends the cl content to 32 bits so it fits in register eax
print  str$ (eax), 13, 10	; Displays the value of eax registry

inkey "Press any key to continue..."

exit  						; Closes the console
 
end main					; Ends the main label

Picture of the result:

jqq5mo.png819×460

Read full topic
